person.note: In this pseudepgraphic composition Described as one of Μαθηταὶ … ̓κτώ (eight disciples).
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Was contemporary of Jesus.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
This is Alexandra (4) G/F, in vol. 1, p. 313.

In vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.2, pp. 49-50 I described the unclear position vis-à-vis Jewishness of Herod’s attendants and freedmen. This would be just as true for his or his household’s slave. It may be assumed that Jews habitually circumcised their male slaves. Whether this meant they were Jews is unclear (see C. Hezser, Jewish Slavery in Antiquity[Oxford 2005]30-1.). Thus I include in this addendum those overlooked in vol. 1, but as doubtful.
On such dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.2, p. 51.

Described in the text together with Nicodemus (3) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 298, Nathanel (2) B/M in vol. 1, p. 200 and Joseph (29) B/M, in vol. 1 p. 151, as οἱ καὶ συνέφαγον αὺτῷ (those who ate with him) in the wedding of Simon (2) in Cana.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Was contemporary of Jesus.
On this form see vol. 1, under Alexander (19) G/M, p. 258.

In Greek – ̓Ιοπῖτις.
Jewishness suggested based on Palestinian provenance, but Jaffa was not an exclusively Jewish city, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. IJO considered it non-Jewish.

In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read אנדרימכס. On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the interchange of י and ו see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.1, p. 18.
In Syriac – ܟܗܢܐ.

Appears in a late description of the visit of Alexander to Palestine, probably influenced by the Alexander-novel literature. On this literature and its role in Jewish literature see e.g. W. J. van Bekkum, A Hebrew Alexander Romance According to MS London Jews’ College no. 145(Louvain 1992) 1-13.
This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of Alexander’s visit to Palestine, see Introduction 7.1.
In Greek –Βοστρηνός. On this location see Introduction 3.2.1.
On the Tomb of the Prophet on the Mount of Olives and the character of the inscriptions read there see Introduction 8.1.2.1.
The editor of these inscriptions considered them Christian, but see previous note.
If the Tomb of the Prophets was a Jewish site, it had to have been in use before the destruction of the Temple, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52, but see previous note.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.. On the transliteration of τ with ת see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.6, p. 21.
The inscription was found in the remains of the destroyed Samaritan Temple, see Introduction 8.1.1.1.
See previous note. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the destruction of the Samaritan Temple.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11, see above, n. 2.
See above, n. 3.
See above, n. 4.

The inscription was found in the Dominus Flevit complex, which was an ossuary burial site during the Second Temple period, and the names from the ossuaries found there are all recorded in vol. 1. But this inscription was not found on an ossuary and the editors assume the cave was reused in the 3rd C, as a coin found in it indicates. If this is an inscription from this later period it is not of a Jew.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.

His conversion may be assumed based on the fact that he was born a Jew and died as a Christian.
This is the year of his martyrdom (13th year of Trajan).

Gaza was not primarily a Jewish city; the market supervisor could be a pagan.
The weight is dated to the 12th year of Claudius, see Introduction 7.1.
In Greek – Σιδωνία. Located in Lebanon.
In Egypt.

His daughter’s name, their origin from the outlying districts of Palestine and the fact that Jewish tombstones were found in this cemetery suggested that he was Jewish. For doubts about this suggestion see G. Bohak, “Good Jews, Bad Jews and Non-Jews in Greek Papyri and Inscriptions,” Akten des 21. Internationalen Papyrologenkongresses, Berlin, 13.-19.8.1995 (Archiv für Papyrusforschung Beiheft 3, Stuttgart-Leipzig 1997) 106.

Identification is based on the Semitic name of the daughter, the theophoric name of the father and of their provenance (in Greek the daughter is described as ̓Ανιτιόχισσα – of Antiochia [in Syria]), but this combination does not necessarily make the man Jewish.
So in no. 387. This name is also recorded, see WGE, 530.
All three versions in no. 388, see previous note.

If this is the name intended, obviously the scribe had added an ε and replaced the second ι with ε, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21.
Epiphanius, ad loc. claims that he was active at the time of the Emperor Trajan. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
On the dating of documentary papyri from the Judaean Desert see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7, p. 53.
In Coptic, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read Κλεοπα. For the form Κλωπᾶ see under Cleopas (3) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 291, where the ω is understood as abbreviating εο.
In this text his son is resurrected from the dead by a miracle perfomed by a Christian and this convinces him to convert.
Shortly after Jesus’ crucifixion.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.

See Urman, “Golan,” 405-6.

The inscription is described as found in a sarcophagus tomb. If it dates to before the destruction of the temple, it is Jewish, see vol. 1, Introduction, 7.6.2, p. 52.
See previous note.
The publication does not include a Greek transcription.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
This looks like the genitive of Λύσιος (WGE, 831-2) but it is found on the same ossuary as the next form, which is a genitive of Λυσίας.
On this form see vol. 3, under Lysias (1) G/M, p. 327.

In Latin – Flavius Neopolitanus.
In Spain.
The person’s provenanc is Siechem, the chief Samaritan city. However, they may have been Roman colonists in the newly founded colony, since they mention their Roman tribal affiliation – Ter(etina).
See above, n. 2.
See above, n. 3.

The ostracon is bilingual. So in the Hebrew. On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4. On the transliteration of τ with ת see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.2.3, p. 19. In the Greek – Νικήρατος.
In Idumea.
The ostracon is Idumean, and the moneylender קוסידע בן חנא is an Idumean, as his name indicates, but he lent money to a Jew, as the name of his father indicates.
The ostracon is dated to the sixth year. The editor assumes this is the sixth year of Ptolemy Philadelphus, see Introduction 7.1.
On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.

person.bibl: Solomon of Basra,Book of the Bee, 89
person.note: In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read נקדמוס. On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.2.1, pp. 13-4.
Appears in a list following the words ܫܡܗܐܵ ܝܢ ܕܪܥܵܘܬܐ ܐܝܬܝܗܘܢ ܗܠܝܢ (the names of the shepherds are these:).
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event took place at the birth of Jesus.
In Transjordan.
This inscription is clearly a pagan one, commemorating the dedication of an altar to Zeus. However, the name of his father is probably Jewish, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.4.1, p. 52.
The inscription is dated to the 10th year of the Emperor Hadrian, see Introduction 7.1.
This is an abbreviated form of the name. On such abbreviations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.1, p. 13.
This is Mariam (8) B/F, in vol. 1, p. 242.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
He is the Virgin Mary’s grandfather, and so would have lived at this time.
In Greek – πόλεως Φρωτης (citizen of Phrote).
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.

So in the London – BL Harl. 5508 (400), the Oxford Opp. Add. fol. 23 and the Vatican 134 Mss, as well as the Venice and Vilna prints. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. For this form see vol. 4, under Pāpā/Pāpai (2) I/M, p. 197.

So in the Munich 6, New York – JTS Rab. 1623\2 (EMC 271) and the New York – JTS Rab. 218 (EMC 270) Mss as well as the Spanish print, see previous note. On this form see vol. 1, under Napah S-H/M, p. 295. This may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
So in the Munich 95 Ms, see above, n. 2. On this Iranian name see vol. 1, under Parnakh B/M, p. 208. This too may be a scribal “correction,” see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
Although only mentioned here, in BT, his son transmits a tradition in the name of a tanna, see vol. 1, Introduction 5.7.2, pp. 42-3.
See previous note, and vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.

In vol. 3, I included the Egyptian variation on this name – Πτολᾶς (see vol. 3, pp. 648-9). Perhaps a variation of that name is intended here. What a plural dative suffix is doing here is unclear.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

Reading reconstructed by editor according to other name, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11, see previous note.
See previous note..

Reading reconstructed by editor according to other name, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.

The editor thought he was Christian, because the inscription was reported to have been found with other Christian inscriptions, and preserved in a collection of a Christian institute in Jerusalem, but the name of his father may suggest Jewishness, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 3, under Socrates (3) G/M, p. 377.
In Greek – Σιδωνίου.

Jewishness is suggested based on his wife’s name – the feminine form of the Hebrew male name מתתיה, but since this is the only sample of this form, it cannot be used as decisive, and see also vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.4.1, p. 52.
In Greek – ̓Αντιοχεύς(in Syria) τῳ γένει συνήγορος.
In Egypt.
Described as συνήγορος̔πὲρ ̓Ιουδαίων (advocate of the Jews), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.1.2, pp. 27-8.
The events in which he is involved take place during the reign of the Emperor Trajan. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
Both forms and the nominative Τελεσίστρατοςare found on the ossuary. This last is an abbreviation see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.1, p. 17.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Tryphon (4) G/M, p. 308. On the medial נ in the final position see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.3.5, pp. 30-1.

Although almost all the vowels in this name seem incorrect, I assume this is the same name, because it is, in the end, nearest to it. For such variations in vowels see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.5, p. 13.
In Greek – μν θαυμων, see editorial comment.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
In Greek – ̓Αραδία. Situated north of Tripolis in Lebanon.

Jewishness is suggested based on his daughter’s name – the feminine form of the Hebrew male name מתתיה, but since this is the only sample of this form, it cannot be used as decisive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.4.1, p. 52.

div.note: WGE, 163 records the form ̓Ασταχύων and LGPN IIIB records ̓́Ασταρχος.
This name is recorded neither in WGE, nor in all the volumes of LGPN, but it is recorded in Preisigke, NB, 91.
WGE did not know this form as a Greek name, but see LGPN II, 184.
Greek, WGE, 444. This is probably a Greek theophoric name, mentioning the Greek chief God – Zeus, see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1130. The word means “grandfather” in Greek.
